Entry.1:
Arrived here from Weymouth exactly a week ago

During the ensuing time I was put in a draft for France, issued with kit for service gave in all extra kit not required so that I was left with what I stood up in & a change of underclothes.

Next we were to leave last Thursday, then the draft was broken up & another lot including
Entry.2:
was formed.

That went away & I was in the next one when an idiot in my hut caught mumps & now we are isolated for 24 days.

Shall write home to see if Dad can come down for the week-end.

The routine is drill, fatigues & route marches.
Entry.3:
Still in isolation. Have continued so far with route marches every day.

Every day we march from 9 till 11.30 & 2 till 3.30 or 4, with the exception of some fatigues.

Yesterday we had an all-day stunt. We went to Wollop, a village near here, & had our rations at an inn supplemented by beer, cider & sloe gin.

During the day we marched 20 miles & had a very enjoyable time.

Today we were drilled for some hours and informed that we are to make part of an emergency ambulance to go to Bulford next Tuesday for the Kings Review.

That will be a new experience, to be reviewed by the King, but it will be rather tiring I fancy
Entry.4:
Definite news today that we go to Bulford on Tuesday for King’s Review.

Heard from Dad today that he cannot come down just now; I fancy it will not be possible to see him before I go over.

Were drilled all the afternoon by a Capt.

Feeling fairly fit & happy & am quite anxious to get over to France to try my luck

It will need to be good I fancy for the boys who left in the draft after the one I should have gone on have lost several wounded already

It is fairly obvious that we shall strike the big advance right in the middle

I don’t feel particularly down in the dumps about the war, but I must admit that the Army has no attractions for me.

I have not heard from Rita for weeks, but the U boats probably account for some letters from her. Nevertheless I feel a little anxious.

Weather improving just now & the real Spring is apparently nearly on us

Act 4 Scene 2
Entry.6:
Field Ambulance at Wareham.

During isolation I came to the conclusion that it would be useless to try to get back to the
Entry.7:
for even if I did it would be only to go stretcher-bearing.

I therefore made application to be sent here as N.C.O., but although I repeated the application no reply was vouchsafed.

Tried to get paraded to A.D.M.S. when he reviewed us on the day before the King’s Review, but Craig, the W.O. refused, so I waited till after we had returned

from Bulford & immediately went over to Tidworth to see Col. McWhae, A.D.M.S.

He, with no ado, gave me what I asked for,- a transfer to
Entry.8:
Field Ambulance with addition of a note recommending my dispensary capabilities.

I had some trouble with Mr Craig & also with Major Johnson, O.C. Parkhouse, but we got over that & here I am.

The King’s Review was a days enjoyment.

We left early and arrived at Bulford marched straight to our position.

Whilst we were standing

easy there the King arrived & crossed by us to the Pavilion, for we were on the extreme left: More standing at ease while he reviewed the troops starting from the extreme right

It was a magnificent sight to see the thousands of troops lined up on that huge field

I happened to be in the second section & was therefore quite near to him when he arrived at our end.

Then came the march past.

The troops went to the right extreme of the field & wheeled round so as to come back pa the Pavilion

in column of companies. As we progressed toward the other end we saw the first troops begin to march past. They were the Light Horse, and looked absolutely magnificent in their long lines.

After marching quite a mile we marched past in fairly good order, the review was at an end.

While the mass of troops was sitting down in the left corner of the field the King came along on his way out, & one & all left their food to help the parting cheers

I came down here yesterday evening & was put in H Section.

Tomorrow morning I parade in front of the C.O. Col. Marks & present my credentials.
Entry.9:
Yesterday morning I paraded to C.O. and he told me what I already knew, i.e. that the ambulance had three dispensers, but one was an infantry man. If his transfer went through he would get the place; if not I would be called up. 

For the present my services were urgently required for fatigues.
Entry.10:
kind of him.

Yesterday & to day I have been spraying mumps huts & mounting guard over swill tubs; neither very intelligent, but fairly easy, & leaving plenty of time on my hands.

Astonished to find that the infantryman dispenser is my old friend from Brisbane –Syd Baker.

It is rather an awkward position to be waiting to step into the shoes of such a decent chap.

He is self effacing & modest & I really believe I is anxious to consider all others before himself

He transferred to 

the infantry a year ago & went to France with them.

An instance of his modesty is the fact that he went up to the Col. after I had told him about the dispensary job, & asked him to get a definite answer in regard to his transfer, as he did not want 
to stop other people
 from getting on, or words to that effect
Entry.11:
To day I have been exerting myself in the role of cart horse, on blanket fatigue with the Q.M.Sgt.

Yesterday was Anzac Day, but being our duty week we worked (A Section), & were promised a holiday next week.

As a matter of fact I managed by luck to get a couple of hours of after dinner and in the evening I went to a show at the Empire with Alec Nunan, whom I have dug

up in B Section of the Ambulance.

He & Billy & I were together at Tel El Kebir and on the journey over through France.
Entry.12:
Cook’s fatigue today & on the whole easy. Scored a good dinner out of it anyhow.

Went for a walk this evening and hired a byke for next Wednesday

Probably be able to go to Weymouth on that day.

Weather still warm and good.

Press is clamouring for food economy & every day the submarine trouble grows before our eyes, so that it is becoming quite evident that despite Germany’s very serious plight, we are faced with a critical few weeks ahead.

If we can last out & beat the submarines this summer we are through. If not, all goes for nothing & Germany wins.
Entry.13:
Had half holiday in return for working (?) last Wednesday. Hired cycle for afternoon & starting at 12.30 p.m. for Bournemouth, reached there, after a splendid ride, at 2 pm

Found Aunt had moved from Lincoln Avenue to Orcheston Rd, near Em’s.

Aunt was astonished to see me, & so was Bert, who by good luck, I found at home.

Em amp; her husband (who is the Sec of the Chamber of Trade) were both in & so was Rachel. 

In fact I think I saw all except those on active service.

As a matter of fact I was delighted with a very pleasant afternoon. The last time I saw them all was just before leaving for Australia, but they impressed me just exactly the same for all the change I have gone through.

Even the dim memories I have of those days long ago, when as a little kiddie cousin Jim made me sing “I’m a Dandy” are all pleasant, They seem to make one at home & one of the , straight

away, & that is why I like them.

They are all ordinary Hampshire people, none of them , unless it be Ron Plumer who certainly is a good business man, but they have hearts of gold Em especially is a hard working genial loving & loveable woman.
Entry.14:
Route march.

We started at 9.30 & marched across country, including too big hills, to Worbarrow, a little village right on the sea. It is situated in a cove lined with large white cliffs.

Actually on the sea there

were only a couple of houses & a coastguard station, & after a snack of bread & cheese, when we went on to the pebble beach, we only sighted one man & a few girls, evidently spending a quiet holiday.

Only A Section went on this march & it was led by Capt Merrilees, known as Gertie & Mary Lees on account of his girlish ways. He appears to me to be a very decent chap, albeit a trifle fussy. On that march he was very good as a leader anyhow.

By the time we reached home we had covered
Entry.15:
17 miles, but I was in no way tired by it. In fact I went to a concert with Aleck Nunan in the evening.

Friday 4th May

Today was spent in lectures to give us an easy time after yesterday.

The morning lecture by Cpl Merrilees dealt with the circulation, & the afternoon by the same, dealt with the digestion.
Entry.16:
Kit inspection in the morning & in the afternoon walked five miles to

Wool where I had tea walked back

It was hot walking there but very cool coming back for a chilly wind sprang up. Accomplished quite a record in walking back in 50 minutes – without a rest & an average of a mile for ten minutes.
Entry.17:
Brigade church parade in the morning attended by the General.

Slept during the afternoon & went to the pictures with Alex. Nunan in the evening

He told me various

tales of his adventures with girls at Harefield Hospital & in walking afterwards we met Scotty from Weymouth who is detail to a Battalion in this Brigade

The above artistic design was put in while I was being “spoken to” by a decent chap in the hut. He was telling me of an experience he had when at the Isle of Wight on 48 hour’s leave recently.

He met a teacher by accident who invited him home & in the end he spent his night in Freshwater at this residence
Entry.18:
Inoculation today which I missed, & on that account Capt Straun (who is likely to be our major) lectured us on bleeding wounds & antiseptics.

Both were interesting the former characterised by the undressing (partial) of various of of number, & consequent stoppage of all kinds of arteries with numbers of imaginary lives saved

A story brought up incidentally is worth recording: -

Two men had their legs shot off in a dressing station & the only stretcher bearer

near succeeded in arresting bleeding for ten minutes until help arrived. He managed it by kneeling between the men & pressing with thumb & long finger respectively in the groin pressure points, thus stopping four arteries with two hands.

In that & other deeds he was subsequently awarded the V.C.
Entry.19:
Laziness in not writing up before.

This is a perfectly horrid day muggy, wet & oppressive

Played piano for two church parades this

morning & wrote letters till dinner time.

This afternoon I read & wrote - (the former a treatise on education) & this evening, after going to a picture show till eight, walked to the village & had cups of tea at the Congregational Hall

Last Sunday our unit held a special church parade in St Martin’s Church in the second oldest in England. This was the first service since 1887, -- Jubilee Year.

We ran a choir & I played the harmonium.

In the afternoon

I called on two teachers who live just outside Wareham, in response to an invitation sent through Davidson of Parkhouse. They entertained me well with food & music & showed me over the School

On Tuesday night I went to London on 48 hours leave & found Billy Molloy was staying at home while working at Headquarters.

While in town I saw “Damaged Goods” the play on the great Scourge, & it made a great impression on me for it was well acted.

It is the first play that has been produced in

England which deals with the vexed question of V.D. & the fact that it is the first is a good instance of the hideous hypocritical attitude of the present day moralists.
Entry.20:
Went for route march with full packs up, to Corfe Castle, an easy days march all told & made pleasant by the two hours halt in which we explored the Castle.

The chief point of interest as far as I was concerned was the fact that a

sailor once stood on the top of the highest remaining wall. It must have required some nerve ----- more than I possess at present.

We traced the original castle. It stands (or its ruin does rather) on an isolated hill which is pointed both at the front & rear. The front faces towards where the sea lies some dozen miles to the south, & it is reached by a stone bridge over the dry moat

Immediately inside the gate is a stretch of green sward sloping steeply upwards towards the Castle

The old staircase ran up

from the left corner sheer up to the summit of the hill on which the Castle stands, while round the edge of the steepest part of the hill the outer rampart runs & the ruins of the corner bastions still stand.

We climbed up as high as possible into the part which was once the main hall & noted that the building was evidently once four storeys high.

History – Saxon (I think) of about Alfred’s time -- Edward the Martyr’s death -- In Elizabeth’s time the owner was Governor

 supreme in the Isle of Purbeck -- Cromwell demolished it when hunting the Royalist’s party.

Went to tea with the teachers again on Wednesday & enjoyed a musical evening.
Entry.21:
Went for a route march to day – 15 miles with full pack – effects nil, so I am in fairly good nick.

The route lay through the plantation & birch country which is common

round here. The effects are chocolate brown, sepia, myrtle green & light green, which are produced respectively by the plantation cone covered soil, the fir-tree trunks the oak foliage & the birch foliage. The bright blue background of the sky makes a fitting blend with the harmony of such a scene.

If this war were over it strikes me as an ideal holiday to camp out in such country & live a wild free life, unfettered by any conventions. Following the idea on I fancy that such a life would be

delightful for a honeymoon.

Perhaps I may be able to realise such an idea, if Rita is agreeable, & I return safely.

Every day finds me more disgusted with the conservatism of England; the ridiculous clinging to old ideas, such as the old weights & measures (to mention only one common instance), the hypocritical & prudish ideas on morality; all fill one with a feeling of contempt for those who have allowed us to become so insular.

The teacher of Landon School has opened my eyes to the hold the 

 

aristocracy (!) of England has held over the Schools until quite recently; in fact even now they have a tremendous influence in scholastic affairs.

For instance Lady Rodgett at the “Hall”, (the occupants of which have always governed the school) would allow no girl leaving school to go into any thing except service, for which she fitted them out; as she owned the houses their parents occupied, they had no other choice. That is a very significant fact, & it happened until within the last few years
Entry.22:
Commenced duty week yesterday, & I, being in the tent division, am on the observation Hosp.

It is a good job 

There are three of us with a Lance Corp who is an oldish steady old chap, who knows his work fairly well, but is not very quick. He is a nice chap.

The other two are young & very straight kind of chaps & full of life.

Went to Bournemouth on Saturday afternoon & saw aunts & uncles.

Heard little Flo play the piano & played myself, & enjoyed the evening

Arrived back at 1 AM.

Went over to the School on Sunday afternoon – stayed till about 8.45 pm

Feel bluey tonight on account of a brush with the enemy, represented by Capt Merrilees – who is a terribly jumpy individual & says the most ridiculous & pointed things. I think his heart is right, but his head runs away with him at times.
Entry.23:
Nothing much has happened but something is about to happen

We are to leave this beautiful town for the miseries of camp on Salisbury Plains

The original rumour said last Wednesday, but fact will make it this Wednesday or Thursday.

Last Wednesday I gave a lesson on Australia to the kiddies of Sandford School. They were interested & greatly responsive.

I have been out frequently to Sandford & spent very happy times there discussing

all manner of topics with the mistress, She has been unfortunate in love affairs & the result is a peculiarly distorted idea of men

She thinks that they are all libertines & that 90% of girls give in to their passions, & those who don’t are not wanted.

Certainly men are bad, but I refuse to believe them to be so bad as that, and I cannot believe that the majority of girls has bad morals. We live in confusing times, but bad as the effects of the war undoubtedly are, they have not reached that level 

In one idea at least I am

in thorough agreement with her & that is the absolute uncertainty of life today

None of us is secure for five minutes together.

It is hard for a man to follow out his ideals honestly under these circumstances, for every hour is a tremendous struggle. But if he gives in & flows with the tide he is only choosing the shadow & sooner or later he will return to search for the substance

No letters from Rita again this mail.

I do so want to have a nice long letter from the dear little girl to encourage me

on the way; but it is not forthcoming. Probably letters have been written but lost in transit.

The daily life of the ambulance has not varied much, & my position is just about the same. I am hovering between the tent division & stretcher bearers at present. If the latter job falls to my lot I shall go through to the last, but I shall not last as long as I should on the tent division.

I must try to scrape together some remnants of shattered faith, & put trust in the workings of providence without fretting from day

to day over the ultimate results of each step I take. That fretting habit is the cause of more unhappiness.
Entry.24:
We started yesterday morning at 5.30 from Wareham. I had goodbye to Mrs Brooks at the School overnight, & on our way through town most of the population waited to see the last of us.

We marched 10 miles before dinner & finished at Blandford (17 miles) at 3 p.m. Here we camp in a big private park on the outskirts of the town

& I assisted as part of the tent division in erecting two bell tents. My feet behaved very well & altogether I was pleased with the way I maintained cheerfulness during the most dreary parts.

Town was placed out of bounds, but the troops went there just the same in approved Australian fashion, & open town was declared at 7.30 p.m., being all that was possible on the part of the authorities.

General Anthill (in charge of the Brigade) is rather a bullying kind of man

& does not seem to lose an opportunity of letting loose at our Col. who takes it all smiling.

Yesterday afternoon one of the Staff captains came bustling up, on our arrival, & quite excitedly 
informed
 pointed out a flag marked pitch as our ground on which to bivouac.

“Yes” answered the Colonel “are’nt they pretty flags?”

We left Blandford at 6.30 this morning & are now a further nine miles on our way. We reached here at midday & stay the night in a fine hilly paddock

overlooking a valley.

The position is 3 miles south of Shaftesbury, through which we should march to finish with 13 miles tomorrow.
Entry.25:
Fovant

We arrived in Fovant Camp at midday on Friday & found everything ready for us – even beds made

The position is not nearly so bad as we had been led to expect, & our actual camp is rather good.

Lord Werley reviewed the
Entry.26:
Brigade on Saturday & the Ambulance was adjudged the smartest on parade

I don’t get at all well with A Section officers, however, They dont seem particularly struck with me, & on the whole I am not strangely taken with them so, the feeling is mutual.

From now on I have no desire whatever for stripes. As long as the war lasts I will work, but then finish with all things military.
Entry.27: Today I applied to be returned to the
Entry.28:
Fld Amb as permission was given to those who served on Anzac.

Lately I have got very dissatisfied with

this unit, chiefly because I have felt & am quite certain that I have been deliberately pushed in the background, which is hard after 2 yrs service.

Went on 2 days leave last Sunday at reveille, but to return in time meant catching 5.40 from Waterloo on Monday afternoon, so I left it till Tuesday morning & was given one day
Entry.29:
Field Punishment – quite normal & also perfectly fair.

Had an evening at the theatre for my trouble.

Not feeling in the pink lately for some reason. Had four letters from Rita in a fortnight much to my pleasure.

Have been writing to her every day lately, as I know what great pleasure they will give her.

We are supposed to be going either in one or three months, which is not known for certain.

We made our wills this week
Entry.30:
The letters to Rita of the last fortnight will, in them selves, serve as a diary, so there is no need to keep so closely to this

We are still drilling hard & the general effect of this camp & surroundings on the men is depressing.

It is not that there is not good scenery near, but the actual camp commands only a bare hill, & that naturally has a depressing effect.

 

Wilton Church 

St Nicolas

St & Mary

Foundation
Entry.34:
Earl of Pembroke assisted by mother

Cost £ 30,000

Style Lombard – develop. Of old Byzantine or later Romanesque

Represents Basilica or Roman Court of Justice

Earl of Pembrokes Estate 

School 1660

Title 1551

Stepping stones

Archway containing Norman statuary

Nero Caesar Hannibal

Statues from Italy of Venus Medici Nero

Lord 

Entrance only part of original left.

Cardinal Wolsey’s walk.

Painting in house of Cardinal walking alone

Burial pound of men who fought against the 

Back of house.

remainders of the famous cedars of Lebanon 1660
Entry.36:
– 14

Top blew off

Rear part of house work of Imgo Jones 1660

Shakespeare 1700 statue In March light from invet at 6.30 7 hours on ShakespearShakespeare

Fountain on side of house Inigo Jones 1660

Australian gum tree (stringy bark) – 

growing in garden () on side of house

Old drayser

(Old front = East (Wolseys)

Entry.37:
Two leaves in London.

one – returned A.W.L. & received a day’s F.P. No 2.

Second quite unexpected & so enjoyable all the more.

Lily’s birthday - small autograph album must better it later. Small disturbance at home with D.Q. with Molloy for the front apparently.

Have written him, but would not call when in London

Mental upheaval that caused, the letters to Rita to become more regular have not subsided

Am advanced in a good many ways. – a little firmer in character – less prodigal with money – more inclined to do any work at hand – and 
happier

Great lapses from time to time, but am fighting as hard as I ever fought before to once & for all make something of myself. The glimpses I get from time to time of what I might become if I persevere make the fight well worth while.

Yesterday we attended a brigade battle manoeuvre

Reveille 5 AM, moved off 6.15 & picked up 3 battalions marching about 3 miles from here.

at 4 miles turned off road in bush & advanced quietly by the side of hedges, across fields, keeping in touch with rear of infantry.

At about 10 our outposts got into touch with enemy (69th Batt) outposts who retired our main column, just as dinner was 
ready
 timed (Dinner. one piece bread & salmon)

Next we moved off & negotiated a large hill & a ridge, coming on massed infantry in a hollow.

Here was General directing operations of infantry to attack main position of enemy on large hill topped

with wood, a mile away.

Drizzle turned to steady rain & we
Entry.38:
retired to a wood where dressing station was imagined to have been erected.

Attack did not develop, but we abandoned fighting at about 3 to return in heavy rain.

Humour: rice on feet- - short-cuts - climbing hills & collapsing – sliding down other side & collapsing. Gyrations of stretcher bearers on muddy hills. Capture of runners by our own men.

Relations with Cpl Merrilees & Major Strachan have a little improved lately.

Fancy latter is inclined to have favourites & does not care a rap about the rest as individuals. If he gets a dislike for a chap he works off his feelings by mean actions.

Gertie has developed his eccentric mannerisms & is a little less popular than before In some ways has improved & in others not

Generally less noisy.

Means well but fails lamentably.

Wrote & Curry yesterday.

View from front of camp
Entry.39: Fortnight ago today news reached Fovant that the Anzacs were to move off for Perham en route to old units. Previous evening our concert party (under Geo Street) gave a performance. It was sports day & farewell dinner of
Entry.40:
Good food & plenty – with beer & cigarettes.

We presented “East Lynnoleom” a burlesque on East Lynne, & I took part of Sir Frances Levison. Successful & complemented on following morning by officers.

Arrived Perham on Sat.

evening & found it a rather miserable details camp.

Discovered broken rib from performance – appointed hut corporal when in C Coy & later transferred to B.Coy.

Yesterday

Inspected on Monday by the Duke of Connaught on a hill near the camp.

On Friday – yesterday – marched over in company with other A.M.C men, A.S.C. & Engs, to Parkhouse.
Entry.41:
the beginning & the end of this book is Parkhouse

Between times I have accomplished absolutely nothing from a military point of view but in every moral sense I am better.

The training I had with the
Entry.42:
has done me good physically, & the difficulties & oppositions followed by failures, have made me more determined, less egotistical, more humble & generally far better.

Am marked A Class & expect to leave in next draft (first for 6 weeks & more) for France.

Better luck in the future!

Nil desperandum.
